Award.AwardTitle: Identification of Cellular Amino Acid Export Mechanisms in Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit
The goal of this project is to discover mechanisms through which plants export nitrogen nutrients from leaves to the growing organs. This transport process is essential for optimal plant growth and health, as transport activity affects the accumulation of nutrients in edible parts of the plant, such as seeds and tubers. Grains used as feedstock are often low in protein and essential amino acids, which need to be supplemented at cost to the farmers. Reliance on a single staple food (maize, cassava, rice) is common in the developing world, and often leads to malnutrition because these plant organs are poor in protein and/or essential amino acids. Increasing the capacity of plants to export nitrogen nutrients to edible parts of the plant is expected to lead to more nutritious food containing more protein, and is hence a highly desirable trait. The team led by Okumoto has developed biosensors for glutamine, the amino acid plants mainly use for the export of nitrogen from leaves to edible parts. By using this sensor, the team aims at discovering genes responsible for glutamine export from plant cells. The discovered genes will further be analyzed by Pilot and Okumoto, whose expertise areas are in the transport process of plants. Selected genes will be used for creating plants that are more efficient in nitrogen transport to the storage organs.

Broader Impacts
Plants are familiar to all of us as sources of food, fiber and fuel. Since the process of nitrogen export has an impact on plant growth, and their quality and quantity as food source, this is a great topic to stimulate the interest of high school students and engage them in early scientific research activities. Dolan is the principal investigator of the Partnership for Research and Education in Plants (supported by a Science Education Partnership Award from the National Center for Research Resources). Through this program, high school students conduct authentic scientific research by challenging Arabidopsis mutants with various treatments that have not been tested previously. Okumoto, Pilot and Dolan will collaborate with high school students to investigate the roles of genes discovered through this project. To increase diversity in the academic environment, undergraduate and graduate researchers from underrepresented groups will be recruited through the Multicultural Academic Opportunities Program at Virginia Tech, with whom Okumoto has an established relationship as a participating mentor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to identify and characterize amino acid exporters in plants. Amino acids are found in high concentrations in the long-distance transport systems (i.e. xylem and phloem) of the plant body, hence considered a nitrogen “currency” traded between plant organs. At the beginning of this project very little was known about how amino acids are exported from the cells in which they are made to be transported to other part of the plants.

 

Our first focus was the family of proteins called Usually Mutiple Amino acid Move In and out Transporters (UMAMITs), some of which were previously reported to function as facilitators for amino acids and their derivatives. By screening 44 UMAMIT members by quantifying amino acids secreted by UMAMIT-expressing yeast cells, we have discovered additional UMAMIT members that export amino acids when expressed in yeast cells.The functional properties of the 44 members of the family was systemiatically studied in yeast. About 2/3 of them are able to export amino acids from yeast, showing various amino acid specificities and efficiencies. Subcellular localization was also systematically investigated, showing that many proteins were addressed to the plasma membrane or the vacuolar membrane. Phylogenic analysis of all plant UMAMIT suggested a large diversity of protein function and role in the plant.

 

One of the UMAMIT genes, UMAMIT14, was further characterized. Our study showed that the gene is involved in exporting amino acids from the root phloem to the surrounding root tissues. We have also shown that the function of UMAMIT14, along with another UMAMIT protein (UMAMIT18), is important in secreting amino acids from roots.  This finding is particularly exciting since secretion of amino acids from roots are speculated to be involved in the interactions between plants and microorganisms in the rhizosphere, but so far no molecular mechanism that is involved in controlling the secretion has been identified. The results obtained in this study provide an opportunity to study how amino acids affect such interactions by changing the amount of amino acids secreted from the plant roots. The results have been submitted for a review for publication.

 

We have also identified a couple of UMAMITs (24 and 25) that are putative amino acid exporters in seeds. We currently hypothesize that these transporters are involved in delivering amino acids to the developing seeds, and have obtained preliminary data to support our hypothesis. Since seeds are the main plant organs that are consumed as feed, food and fuel, the composition of seeds is of particular importance. Our results could lead to a novel mechanism to manipulate the composition of the seeds by changing the amino acid transport ,which is believed to be an important factor that determines the seed composition.

 

In addition to UMAMIT family proteins, we have screened around 300 proteins for amino acid export activities. We have newly identified a gene family called DMPs (DUF679 Membrane Proteins) that are capable of exporting amino acids from yeast cells. These genes are heavily induced during senescence, a process in which the plant organ undergoes programmed cell death and exports the released nutrients. The significance of DMP’s capability to export amino acids is now under investigation.

 

The project also provided tools for studying amino acid transport. The Gln sensor used for this study was further improved during the course of this study and the results have been published. An yeast strain with minimal endogenous amino acid transport has also been created thorough this grant.
